summary: Barry Harrelson was involved with the CIA's interactions with the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) regarding the release of JFK assassination records. He appears to have been a point of contact within the CIA for the ARRB, dealing with issues such as the release of CIA employees' names, the handling of information related to overseas stations, and compliance with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act. He received briefing questions from Michelle Combs regarding CIA's Directorate of Science and Technology (DS&T) and Directorate of Operations (DO). Harrelson also corresponded with John Pereira regarding concerns about releasing CIA employees' names in JFK records. The documents indicate his involvement spanned from at least 1995 to 1997, focusing on navigating the complexities of declassifying and releasing sensitive information while protecting CIA personnel and ongoing operations.
significance: Barry Harrelson played a role in the CIA's response to the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act, specifically in managing the release of information and addressing concerns related to the protection of CIA personnel and sensitive operational details. He served as a key point of contact between the CIA and the ARRB during the declassification process.
